candidates.title: feat: add tui directly into dioxus mainline
Add options for compilation on systems that lack libappindicator3
candidates.body: Possible fix for #281

candidates.title: feat: canoncialize assets for macOS, Windows, and Linux
candidates.body:
This PR adds the right relative pathing for assets when bundled through cargo-bundle.

It's never been this easy to include an image in your Rust `.app`! :)

I don't have any other machine than a mac box so I can't test alternate implementations.

https://crates.io/crates/directories

- [x] macOS

These targets do not provide a straightforward way of bundling assets. I've opted to make it the asset dir configurable instead.
- [ ] windows
- [ ] linux (rpm)
- [ ] linux (deb)

candidates.title: feat: integrate fermi into the main repo
candidates.body:
This PR adds fermi: https://github.com/dioxusLabs/fermi our prototype global state management solution built on the concept of state atoms.

The Fermi pattern fits into Rust pretty well, so I don't have any issue taking fermi on as the "blessed" way of global state management for Dioxus apps. By including Fermi into Dioxus main, we can teach fermi in our main docs - getting new users up and running faster than having to hunt for a new library.

However, it's locked behind a feature flag, so you do need to go out of your way to enable it.

candidates.title: Make all packages which require futures-channel ask for the same version
candidates.body: If they aren't the same then Cargo cannot resolve a working version for some reason.

candidates.title: Use futures-channel instead of async-channel in rIC/rAF code
candidates.body: This PR re-uses the dioxus-core futures-channel dependency instead of pulling in the async-channel dependency.

candidates.title: Update to wry 0.13; support IPC, devtool, and feature flags
candidates.body:
First of all: Thank you for this amazing project!
I had already slightly more fun with this than with tauri itself, even though it stands on the shoulders of it (wry, tao).

I know it's a lot at once, but the wry 0.13 upgrade led me down a rabbit hole.

What changes:
- general dependency updates as much as possible (not only wry)
- switch from RPC to IPC handler, fix message (de)serialization
- modularize some code pieces
- adjust module/function/struct/enum visibility where it made sense (not all need to be pub)
- general cleanups

If something is not to your liking or you want something split up differently, I can try to cut separate PRs.

Note: I tested it with some examples and a local project, all on a Win10 machine.

candidates.title: Add default desktop icon
candidates.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17541209/153717779-422f26e4-cff6-4a4d-a12b-bed6f095599d.png)

**Tested on windows only**

Related: #213

candidates.title: feat: use serde-wasm-bindgen crate for speedup
candidates.body: This PR uses the crate suggested by @t1m0t to use a different flavor of converting strings to JsValues. On my machine, this results in a performance improvement of about 20% and a size reduction of 10%.

candidates.title: Feat: abstract the router on a per-platform basis and add docs
candidates.body:
This PR adds docs to the router and makes it possible to work locally.

The local router is implemented simply as a list of strings with a configurable max stack.

I would like to add deep linking through something like "ondeeplink" but that won't make it into this PR unfortunately.

candidates.title: fix: remove code generation entirely
candidates.body:
It's a nice idea to have tsc generate our js binding files, but it leads to weird changes in PRs and noticeably slows down compilation.

This PR moves the binding code into the jsinterpreter crate so we can service both desktop and web from the same crate and same single `.js` file.

It seems that other projects that use bindings like this just write all their bindings in JS with heavy linting, so that's what we're going to follow until it becomes impossible.

Also, as a side-effect, we've fixed #173

candidates.title: chore: make the js interpreter its own crate so we can rely on it in web/desktop
candidates.body:
This crate makes the interpreter its own crate so we can actually include it in web/desktop without copying files before publishing.

Should be more reliable.

candidates.title: wip: Makefile setup
candidates.body: Added configuration files to perform `cargo make tests` so that it will run the tests in all packages where the root Makefile has a link with and allow runtime tests inside a browser.

candidates.title: Fix the license field in Cargo.toml to be valid SPDX
candidates.body: There's a specific format for this field, because it's intended to be machine-readable.

candidates.title: release: 0.1.8
candidates.body: Not everything is done for 0.1.8, but there's so many changes that the next major release is 0.2.0. This release is mostly for bug fixes

candidates.title: Default asset server
candidates.body: Allow assets to be included relative to the binary root.

candidates.title: Overhaul async hooks: use_future, use_coroutine, use_effect (new)
candidates.body:
This PR overhauls
- [x] use_future to include a dependency array through some very clever rust trait magic (!)
- [x] use_coroutine to be designed explicitly for long-running async tasks
- [x] use_effect as a flavor of use_future that doesn't cause re-renders

candidates.title: Feat: add console_error_panic_hook by default for wasm
candidates.body: Most users who want to build a Dioxus app *also* want stacktraces on panics. This PR just adds that by default, improving the onboarding DX for users so they can actually see *why* their app panicked.

candidates.title: Pass form values as a hashmap on `oninput`/`onsubmit`
candidates.body: This PR closes #117 , adding the "values" field to oninput/onsubmit

candidates.title: The desktop app will default open link in browser
feat: split out rsx into its own crate
candidates.body:
This PR moves separates out the rsx macro and its infrastructure to allow use in an rsx autoformatter and accompanying vscode extension.

This will be part of our 0.1.8 release train alongside the router, optional props, better docs, and more.

Right now, the crate is not released on crates.io but is being relied upon in the fork of the CLI

candidates.title: feat: unify web and desktop interpreter with the same typescript codebase
candidates.body:
This PR unifies the web and desktop interpreter so we only have one codebase to maintain for all JS targets.

It also moves all Dom manipulation into JS which has some light performance improvements.

It also sets us up a TypeScript build so we can strongly type the interpreter code now - which has fixed a few bugs.

closes #22 

Would also make any future changes to the interpreter code easier to maintain since they're only in one place
